Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Few-Body Interactions in Ultracold Quantum Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The present grant is devoted to the study of interactions among a few atoms and possible ways one can achieve quantum control in the regime of ultracold temperatures relevant for quantum gases. Few-atom systems pose some of the greatest challenges facing theorists in atomic physics because of the extremely nonperturbative nature of the interactions. The goal of the proposal is to develop the theoretical tools and explore the basic capabilities and implications of new types of resonances. The investigation will center on controlling the complex multichannel collision dynamics with electromagnetic or static external fields.

A specific aim of the present project is to explore the viability of using a laser field to change the interactions among three or four atoms. The work could potentially have unprecedented impact with far-reaching scientific and technological ramifications. The ability to change atomic behaviors and interactions will have key impact in the quantum control of chemical reaction dynamics. A deep understanding of the ultracold atom interactions will find applications in atomic clocks, quantum information science and for the exploration of many novel phases of matter. The work has an important educational impact as it provides training to graduate and undergraduate students in forefront computational and theoretical research techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This project goal was to elucidate universal properties of few-body systems as well as to develop ways to coherently control interactions in ultracold quantum gases. Here, the importance of few-body phenomena has both fundamental and practical aspects for a variety of quantum phenomena accessible in quantum gases. In fact these efforts are also relevant to other physics subfields, including atomic and molecular, condensed matter, and nuclear physics. In ultracold quantum gases few-body processes can lead to atomic and molecular losses, dictating their lifetime and stability. Therefore, being able to understand the nature of such processes can enable ways to control them. More recently, however, a increasing number of experiments in ultracold gases have been devoted to the exploration of more fundamental few-body effects and have provided a plenitude of observations of a peculiar quantum phenomenon called the Efimov effect. Predicted nearly 40 years ago, the Efimov effect was first experimentally demonstrated in ultracold quantum gases, and this effect serves now as a quantum workhorse to study some of the deepest aspects of universal few-body physics. Our improved understanding can also spawn a new level of control over chemical reactions, over the ability to uncover novel quantum phases, and over new ways to produce stable gases in exotic dynamical regimes. Few-body systems pose some of the greatest challenges facing theorists in atomic physics because of their extremely nonpertubative nature. Below, we summarize our main achievements obtained during the three years of support by the National Science Foundation.

Main Findings

This project has been characterized by the application of our newly developed tools and the related analysis of our findings to research in the field of ultracold atoms and molecules. The three major areas of effort supported in part by this project, namely the universal properties of few-body systems, coherent control of few-body processes, and few-body spinor physics, have greatly benefited from the advances we achieved during this period of support. Our work on the universal properties of few-body systems have been crucial in understanding the stability of quenched unitary Bose gas experiments, which current represent a major effort of the field of ultracold quantum gases. The detailed knowledge of the universal properties of the three-body system allowed us to precise determine the energy and corresponding lifetime of Efimov states as well as the population of such states relevant for the experiment. Our findings motivated further explorations designed to understand the importance of few-body interactions in unitary Bose gases, currently performed at JILA both theoretically and experimentally. Due to the general interest of such systems, these studies will help to understand the nature of the unitary Bose gas and will certainly impact the community broadly. 

Our second main research area concentrated on developing new tools to explore the coherent control of few-body interactions. The theoretical formulation has been developed and has been implemented in our numerical codes. Today, we can calculate two- and three-body properties under influence of radio-frequency and optical external fields. One main focus is to find conditions where one can control the lifetime of Efimov states, as well as three-body losses, by using a blue detuned laser field. Some preliminary results have been presented in conferences, however, a more detailed analysis and exploration will be required to understand the several factors controlling the physics of the problem. One other main focus is the development of coherent control of the interatomic interactions. Here, our studies have shown that the use of radio-frequency fields provides an efficient tool to achieve control. This can impact the field of ultracold quantum gases since it should permit creation of field-induced Feshbach resonances as well as the possibility to quickly change the interactions. These aspects are crucial for explorations of exotic phases in spinor condensates as well as non-equilibrium properties of ultracold quantum gases.

Our studies on few-body spinor physics, representing our third research area, have paved the path to understanding strongly correlated spinor condensates. Our work has shown that inclusion of the spin degree of freedom can seriously impact the Efimov physics. We have found multiple families of Efimov states that can coexist in spinor condensates and have determined the three-body spin-exchange contributions to the mean-field energy. These findings open up a broad range of opportunities to explore novel phases of the matter in strongly interacting spinor gases where few-body interactions play a major role. There has also been extensive headway on Rydberg molecule physics.

Lastly, during the period of support covered by this grant several publications have been published and results have been broadly disseminated in the community via participation at conferences. Our work has helped to expand our knowledge of universal few-body physics in problems relevant for ultracold quantum gases and has suggested new ways in which few-body physics can be explored experimentally and used to probe novel dynamical regimes.
